page.name: Topic 3.1: Setting entry and completion requirements
page.content:
Overview

Effective screening processes help to recruit suitable participants who are likely to succeed in your program. It is also important that you clearly communicate expectations at the outset so participants can decide whether the program is right for them. Entry requirements can vary across pre-apprenticeships, and you should decide what is appropriate based on your target participants and the expectations of your industry and partners.

In setting entry and program requirements, pre-apprenticeship programs should clearly state: 

  • Any academic prerequisites or skills participants will be expected to have when they start the pre-apprenticeship program.
  • Expectations for participation, such as attendance requirements.
  • Requirements for a successful transition into at least one apprenticeship program, including skills, credentials, and other factors (for example, a license to drive, High School Equivalency). Note, where possible, pre-apprenticeship programs should also help participants address gaps in requirements for entry into an apprenticeship.

Review the resources listed below to learn more about how and why to set clear entry and success requirements. 

Recommended reading

  • Transparent entry and success requirements (JFF). This page describes the importance of setting clear entry requirements for pre-apprenticeships and includes several examples from IT programs.
  • Construction pre-apprenticeship programs (Aspen Institute). Read pages 5-7 of this report to learn more about how different construction pre-apprenticeships approach screening and assessment. Consider the differences in approach, depending on the program and participants.
  • Pre-apprenticeship: pathways for women into high-wage careers (U.S. Department of Labor). Read pages 12-14 to learn more about considerations for recruitment and screening. This might also inform how you approach outreach and recruitment, which is covered in Module 4.
